program_name: MISO Load Modifying Resources - Demand Response (LMR-DR) - Missouri
description: Load Modifying Resources (LMR-DR) is MISO's capacity market demand response program available to commercial and industrial customers in Missouri. LMRs are Planning Resources that help Load Serving Entities meet their Planning Reserve Margin Requirements by reducing load during emergency conditions. Resources receive capacity payments through MISO's Planning Resource Auction (PRA) and are obligated to respond during Energy Emergency Alerts. MISO is implementing reforms to create LMR Type I (6-hour notification) and LMR Type II (30-minute notification) effective Planning Year 2028-2029.

service_territories: MISO Midwest Region - Eastern Missouri only (not western Missouri which is SPP territory)

customer_classes.size_threshold_notes: Minimum 100 kW load reduction capability required. Missouri lifted third-party aggregator ban in October 2023, allowing C&I customers 100 kW or larger to participate through aggregators.

seasonal_rates.notes: Planning Year 2024-2025 - Missouri Zone 5 capacity deficit resulted in Cost of New Entry pricing
Planning Year 2024-2025 - Missouri Zone 5 capacity deficit resulted in Cost of New Entry pricing
Planning Year 2025-2026 - uniform across all MISO zones
Zone 5 (Missouri) cleared at CONE price cap
Spring season - significant drop from prior year

performance_rate.notes: LMRs receive capacity payments only, not energy payments. They are emergency resources, not economically dispatched.

penalty_structure.penalty_description: Current penalty for non-performing LMRs is three times the LMP times the MW shortfall. MISO is proposing to change penalty to Value of Lost Load (VOLL) times MW shortfall. VOLL increased from $3,500/MWh to $10,000/MWh effective September 30, 2025. Enhanced penalties are part of LMR reforms for Planning Year 2028-2029.

nomination_bidding.nomination_deadline: Nominations submitted for each Planning Resource Auction (PRA) which occurs annually in April for the following planning year
nomination_bidding.bidding_structure: LMRs clear the Planning Resource Auction at zonal clearing prices. No price bidding allowed - resources are price takers.

enrollment_period.end_date: Resources must be registered and accredited prior to PRA

special_attributes: MISO has never called upon EDRs (Emergency Demand Response) in its history
Missouri lifted third-party aggregator ban in October 2023
MISO is eliminating dual registration of LMR as EDR effective Planning Year 2026-2027
LMR reforms creating Type I (6-hour) and Type II (30-minute) response times effective PY 2028-2029
Resources requiring 4+ hours curtailment capability receive 100% capacity credit

program_evolution.change_description: MISO transitioned from annual to seasonal capacity construct with separate auctions for Summer, Fall, Winter, and Spring seasons
FERC approved reduction of maximum LMR notification time from 12 hours to 6 hours for Planning Year 2023-2024
Missouri Public Service Commission lifted FERC Order 719 opt-out in October 2023, allowing third-party aggregators to serve C&I customers 100 kW+
Missouri Zone 5 experienced 872 MW capacity deficit in Fall/Spring resulting in clearing prices of $719.81/MW-day (Cost of New Entry)
FERC approved increase in Value of Lost Load (VOLL) from $3,500/MWh to $10,000/MWh effective September 30, 2025
MISO filed to eliminate dual registration of LMRs as EDRs effective Planning Year 2026-2027
LMR reforms creating Type I (6-hour notification) and Type II (30-minute notification) expected to take effect in Planning Year 2028-2029

data_sources.source_name: PCI Energy Solutions - What Is a DR LMR in the MISO Market
MISO BPM-026 Demand Response Business Practices Manual
Missouri PSC - Third Party Aggregator Ruling
Enel North America - MISO Demand Response
FERC Approves MISO VOLL Increase to $10K

integration_metadata.notes: BATTERY SUITABILITY ASSESSMENT: LMR-DR program is WELL-SUITED for battery energy storage systems with the following considerations: (1) Behind-the-meter batteries can participate as LMR-DR for capacity payments, (2) 100 kW minimum is accessible for commercial-scale batteries, (3) 6-hour notification time allows adequate planning for discharge events, (4) 4-hour minimum curtailment duration aligns well with typical battery storage durations (2-4 hours), (5) Limited event frequency (16 times/year) minimizes battery cycling degradation, (6) High capacity payments in Missouri Zone 5 ($719.81/MW-day for Fall/Spring 2024-2025) create strong revenue opportunities, (7) Missouri lifted aggregator ban in 2023 enabling third-party participation. IMPORTANT: Battery systems participating as LMR cannot simultaneously participate as Electric Storage Resources (ESR) in energy markets - must choose one participation model. Front-of-meter batteries should consider ESR model instead for energy market participation. CAUTION: Missouri Zone 5 capacity prices are highly volatile - ranged from $10/MW-day (2023-2024 Spring) to $719.81/MW-day (2024-2025 Fall/Spring) to $666.50/MW-day (2025-2026 Summer). This volatility creates revenue uncertainty for long-term project financing.
